wonderwoman bracelet
Half cuff, half linked bars, with built in clasps.
Internal diameter is about 180-190mm so you may need to scale up or down.
Made in SketchUp

The chain is vertical because I only have a 100mm^3 bed.
If desired you can open in sketchup, double click one section and rotate it flat then paste in as many as you want (.5mm space between them. Then copy, rotate 180deg, and offset 50% for the joining links).

title: Armdudroid - Open Source Arduino and Android Controlled Robotic Arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The coolest design for a Robotic arm, fully controllable and programable with an Android App (Armdudroid in Play Store). It uses Arduino Uno, 4 MG995 or MG996R servo, 1 micro 9g servo, bluetooth connection, sensor shield V5 and a Lipo Battery. NO MORE COMPONENTS, it is easy and extremly cheap. All the information (Arduino code, mechanical instructions, parts info...) is in http://www.armdudroid.com Download SKP+STL+DXF to get the ARM and the rest to support Plugins. THE BEST PLUGIN SOLUTION FOR A DOMESTIC ROBOTIC ARM. Thanks for downloading and supporting. Now the APP changed. The code is adapted to control any servo machine.

New Plugin Support, Easier to change plugin and ADDED PLUGIN SUPPORT BASE, so NOW IT IS EASIER to CREATE A PLUGIN! Added NEW PLUGIN! Standard Servo Gripper. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=whlCM8q2Ssc&feature=youtu.be https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vw4D_OW0Irk&feature=youtu.be Added NEW PLUGIN! A digger!

Thanks to all people who visit the project and who like it.
Next steps -->
  • New Android app more powerful.
  • Different typo in www.armdudroid.com .
  • Code on Github.
  • English comments in code.
    • Thanks to GaÃ©tan Collaud for lot of useful suggestions (like changing the web typo to another more readable, the code comments language and the code on github for example) and to offer his help to me. All of you can be part of this project, I want to get that, the best Open Source robotic arm with Plugin system and fully programable with any Android device.

In the future Armdudroid will be controlled not only with an Android device but with other devices like Iphone, PC/MAC/, Windows Mobile... This is the goal. But if you don't have an Android device, you can easily control it with this simple example: http://arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/Knob Enjoy Armdudroid!

New APP to control Armdudroid and any Servo controlled machine, with a New Android code with ENGLISH comments and ALL adapted to control any machine! I will be updating www.WHATAKUAI.com and www.ARMDUDROID.com [email protected]
Visit http://www.armdudroid.com and see how to build the arm!

This is a thumb screw which can be adapted for nut-size thread size, hole or no hole through... Params : (at the top of the file ) margin= extra space in the nut-compartment and the thread hole.. HandleThick = thickness of the handle in mm
handleDiam = diameter of the knob in mm
SpacerHeight = height of the spacer
WallThick = wall thickness around the nut doThreadHole = if true a hole will go through the whole thing
nutAtBottom = false means at the top top the spacer
true means at the knob side.
nutHeight= the height of the nut, the depth of the hole of the nut.
nutDiam= nut diameter measured from flat to flat a bit of margin will be added
ThreadDiam= Diameter of the thread and a bit of margin

title: EasyFix : Fast and easy mounting plate for Goliat extruder

description.text:
You have an Goliat extruder, Tytan3D (http://www.tytan3d.com/en) ? This is a powerful extruder. Unfortunately, it is not easy to use... Thanks to the accessory "EasyFix", the motor will be disassembled / assembled in 15 seconds. It replaces the board linker gear without changing the Goliat extruder. This accessorie fits all Goliat extruder and geared NEMA17 motors.
The EasyFix is an adapter between Goliat and Nema17 motor with gearbox, Type: 17HS13-0404S-PG27. EasyFix is mounted with 4 cylindric screws M3x25 and 2 cylindric screws M3x10 on the Goliat extruder.
EasyFix is an anodized aluminum plate (thickness 5 mm).
See our web site : www.i3dinno.com

description.text:
Mother' day is tomorrow, and if your lazy like me and into giving gift cards instead of making something crafty. 3D print one of these gift card holder which you leave on the table with the Gift card for Mom or put it on the breakfast tray your planing to cook.  
The gift card holder then doubles up as a photograph or a card holder as shown in the picture above.

In case you want to design your own refer to the instructions at
http://www.instructables.com/id/Mothers-Day-Gift-Card-Holder/

The Parthenon from MicrosoftStore is a great print, but at small sizes the thin base is easy to accidentally bend when removing it from the print bed. This can case some of the columns to crack off, so I added a slightly thicker base to prevent this.
I've found that this prints best without solid infill in the columns.

This project was created for the Orlando Scout Show.  It consists of 5 miniature catapults mounted to a base. Each catapult swivels so the kids could aim at different targets. The target wall has panels that flip down when hit with the bean bags, and a pull string that allows the upper and lower targets to be reset individually.
Almost all the pieces are made from 1/8 in 3 layer plywood (luan) and cut on a lasercutter.  Additional instructions on construction are contained in the files.

Material is 3mm birch. Original case (for rpi B) is here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:142608/. Needed same thing but rpi 2 instead of the model b. Took the port measurements/paths for the rpi B+/rpi 2 from this awesome case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:679809 . I have cut the case out and tested it. It works. 3d printed version available:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:819206
Thanks galiettd - http://www.thingiverse.com/galiettd/about Thanks to:
Raspberry Pi Case (with Camera) - raster
http://www.thingiverse.com/raster/about Raspberry Pi model B+ or Pi2 model B case -
keithellis - http://www.thingiverse.com/keithellis/about
ipswitchmakerspace - http://ipswichmakerspace.com/

Modify and produce the svg file:
inkscape - https://inkscape.org Produce gcode for lasercutter:
inkscape plugin - THLaser plugin http://wiki.thinkhaus.org/index.php?title=THLaser_Plugin
or
Sheetcam - http://www.sheetcam.com/ Cut on Area515 (https://area515.org) lasercutter - blacktooth laser cutter machine(https://www.buildyourcnc.com/blacktoothlasercutterandengraver.aspx) controlled by linux cnc (http://linuxcnc.org/).

description.text: Simple 3D print

This is a functioning differential (allows one wheel to rotate faster than another) which makes use of 4 bevel gears. You should print two of every part except DiffInnerAxle5_8.stl.  I printed all parts with a 0.3mm layer height with 15% fill.  The bevel gears have a pitch diameter of 1.5", 18 teeth, and are 1" and 3/4" tall for the tall and short gears respectively.

Print two of all parts, but only one DiffInnerAxle5_8.stl.  Parts were printed using a 0.3mm layer height and 15% fill.  The bore holes of all gears and housings should be filed slightly, so the axles can slide through and rotate easily.  The keys and keyways for the axles should be filed so the bevel gears are press fit onto their respective bevel gears.  Lubricate everything with some silicone spray or other plastic ready lubricant.  I connected the two housings together with a couple of PC case screws (not sure what kind this is). Finally, break the differential in by rotating each axle until it spins easily!

Simple key chain inspired by "Simplusdesign".

Here is a set of spacer shims ranging from .25mm to .50mm in .05mm steps.  Their diameter is set so they will easily drop into the recess in the bottom of a Wades reloaded extruder designed for a Hexagon hot end.  
When I was fitting my new E3D V6 hot ends to my existing Wades Reloaded extruders from my Taz 5, I found that the top head on the hexagon it was replacing was a bit higher than the E3D head relative to the aluminum plate.  I also found that one of my two extruders had a bit more gap than the other.  
So, I designed and printed these to solve the problem.  Yea, I could just print another extruder body specifically for the E3D, but these are so much more simple and less waste and leaves the extruder body able to take either a hex or E3D hot end.

Simply print a set.  Drop the thinnest (.25mm) into the recess in the bottom of the extruder and tighten it to the head plate with the hot end in place.  If there is still slop and you can easily move the E3D, take it apart and step up to the next larger shim.  Stop when you can't easily move the E3D and then step to the next thickest.  That should remove all play in the E3D head.  
Print these at 0.1mm or better, 0.05mm layer height.  Set enough perimeter so it doesn't use any fill.  On a .4mm nozzle, I set Simlify3D to do 10 perimeters and 1 top/bottom layer and it made them solid.  Took less than 5 minutes to print a complete set.  
Print them in some color other than black.  Then write the thickness on them in sharpie when you remove them from your bed.  Then you will know which one is the proper one for each of your extruders.

Ronald Reagan spent quite a bit on military buildup during his presidency, and his pet project was the so-called "Star Wars" program- a system of space-based lasers and missiles that would have given the United States a huge advantage in the Cold War if the program hadn't been so ridiculously expensive!  
Fortunately, the Ronald Ray Gun is much cheaper to produce: all you need is a 3D printer!  (or a friend who has one)  
I accept no responsibility for any Commies vaporized by the Ray Gun.

author: MacGyver

title: Flexy-Hand 2 With Out Flexy filament
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As an e-NABLE volunteer I wanted to make a Flexy-Hand 2 with minimal hassle to test and add to my hand types list that I could make. If you are considering building a Fexy-Hand or Flexy Hand 2 but don't want to go down the difficult learning curve to use flexible filament, a process according to other builders and the various forums, includes extruder gear jams and other frustrations for each of the many filaments, you may want to use this mould to make a complete set of Flexy Joints in one pass with out experimenting on your 3d printer. I have modified the shape of all the hinges slightly to produce a strudy hand action and tested it just for Ooogoo and I am pleased with the results. About a $3.00 investment.
The Mould is sized to fit a flexy Hand2 of 100% scale. If you print a hand at 110% just print the mould at 110% and they should match. Trim as required to align joints exactly.

Reference the instructables below for cautions on making Ooogo, a mixture of Silicone I, with corn starch. I found it easy to make. I just mixed in clear Silicone I, with enough corn starch to turn it white. Do outside or in a well vented area.
If you print the Mould out of PLA you don"t need to prep it. Give it a least 4 hours to dry before removing. Over night to be safe.
Oogoo does not stick to PLA. I could just pushed the hinges out with a flat ended rod. http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/

comments.text: hi , what are the recommend infill for this ? are the mold should be destroy to get the result? thanks
comments.author: DzMakers

comments.text: Infill unimportant (10%). No force on mold. Just push hinge out other side. Does not stick to mold. Mold will not be distroyed.
comments.author: DzMakers

author: rodboudreaux

title: Socket for old cell phone batteries

description.text: Socket for using old cell phone batteries (3.3V-like) in DIY projects. Customization for different types/sizes of batteries can be done by changing dimension-related parameters in the SCAD file.

Use a caliper rule for measuring your battery dimensions (don't forget to check also both "+" and "-" connectors distance from the battery's left side) and adjust the SCAD file with it (using OpenSCAD, for instance) for rendering a suitable/fitting socket for your unit. Plug a generic-dupont wire (male connectors) on each pin hole and use hot glue for fixing them.  
The source code also allows you to enable some support headers on the socket for placing a elastic band and better hold the battery.

description.text: These rods will help you take advantage of the space inside your gun safe.  The top of the rod has neodymium magnets that stick to sheet steel secured under the top shelf of your safe.

Get some 8-32 threaded rods and nuts from the hardware store and heat shrink tubing that will fit over the rods. I suggest using two layers of heat shrink to ensure the threads of the rod don't wear through. Epoxy magnets in place and assemble rods as shown in the photos.  Secure a piece of sheet steel under the top shelf of your safe, I used double stick.

These are some nicely measured gears created in sketchup. I rounded all the edges with Fredo Round corner. There are smoothed and non-smoothed versions available to download. It is recommended to print the smoothed files with support.

• Choose a set of files (smoothed, or non smoothed)
  • Print one case, and two gears of the chosen style
  • Sand until smooth
  • Test for fit
  • If the gears to not spin, use some powdered graphite or petroleum jelly to lubricate

title: Hypocycloid How To Part 2 - Some Experiments

description.text: If you built my Hypocycloid Gear Reduecer (Thing 79231), it is not unlikely that a few questions occurred to you. This Thing will encourage you to explore these questions and learn some interesting things about hypocycloid gear reducers at the same time.

Begin by printing one each of the parts. I am assuming you have already build the example (25:1) included in Thing 79231. These parts are designed to work with it. Note that the gear reduction of Thing 79231 is really 24:1, not 25:1. I discovered this by carefully counting the input revolutions required to get one revolution of the output. Then I studied the behavior to understand what's going on. The lower cam on the rotor contributes 4:1; the upper adds 6:1. Sorry for the confusion! Assemble the parts. You will need:
4 - Bearing 6700ZZ 10x15x4 Shielded Ball Bearing from vxb.com
1 - Bearing 5x10 Shielded 5x10x4 Miniature Ball Bearing from vxb.com
1 â€“ M5x25mm (or the length for your application) hex head bolt. This is the output shaft.
Put two 10mm bearings into the pockets on each rotor.
Put one 5mm bearing into the pocket on the output block.
Put the M5 bolt into the bolt pocket on the output block. For the purpose of these experiments, let's identify the original rotor as a â€œ4x5 lobe rotorâ€. That is, 4 lobe cam on the bottom, 5 lobe on the top. The new rotors you will make are a â€œ4x4 lobe rotorâ€ and a â€œ5x5 lobe rotorâ€. Call the original output block a â€œ6 roller blockâ€ and the new one, a â€œ5 roller blockâ€. The first question that might have occurred to you is, â€œHow can I get less reduction?â€ Well, obviously, you could use fewer cam lobes. But you might be concerned about having so few lobes (2 or 3) on a cam. Will it work smoothly? ( Great question! And one I haven't answered yet - stay tuned!) So another approach might be to use just one cam instead of two. But then how to get an output shaft to turn when the cam moves eccentrically? Time for the first experiment. Dissemble your Hypocycloid Gear Reducer and remove the 4x5 lobe rotor. Put the 5x5 lobe rotor on in its place. Before you put the rest of the reducer back together, turn the motor so the input shaft rotates, moving the rotor eccentrically. Note the motion of the rotor: It's not rotating, only translating in an eccentric pattern! I found this amazing. Now put the 6 roller output block on and assemble the reducer. Make the motor turn (electrically or by hand) and note the output shaft is turning 1/6th turn for each turn of the input (6:1 reduction). So the rotor is only translating, yet the output block is turning. Even more amazing! Let's understand this a little better. Try the 4x5 rotor with the 5 roller output block. Orient the 5 lobe rotor to engage the lower case (which has 5 rollers). Assemble the reducer (using the 5 roller output block) and measure the revolutions of the input required to produce one output revolution. Although the rotor does not rotate, the 4 lobe rotor drives the 5 roller output shaft to produce a 5:1 reduction. â€œWhat if I turn the rotor over?â€ I hear you say. Try it! Put the 4x5 rotor in with the 5 roller output block again. This time, orient the 4 lobe rotor to engage the lower case (which has 5 rollers). Assemble the reducer and measure the revolutions of the input required to produce one output revolution. Post your results and let's see if we all agree. Now for another obvious question. â€œHow about if I just want a little less reduction. Can I use a 4 lobe rotor on both sides?â€ I'm glad you asked, 'cause that was my first question. Install the 4x4 lobe rotor and the 5 roller output block and assemble the reducer. Now there are 5 rollers and a 4 lobe rotor on both levels. I expected a 20:1 reduction. What happens? And, no, you didn't break anything. These experiments should teach you some useful things about the Hypocycloid Gear Reducer and help you design one that meets your needs. Have fun!

description.text: Designed for pd-LAunch, the kick-off of a Los Angeles based patching circle (for patching languages like Pure Data and Max/MSP). We had a series of videos of Miller Puckette lectures we wanted to be able to distribute on USB stick. I designed this enclosure as a special edition version of the stick. The stick is shaped like a message box in Pd, and can be modified with any message text. "bang" is a special Pd message that makes things go. "pd-la" is the name of our patching circle. I designed these on ViaCAD, but exported DXF files of each part. The Corel Draw file has all the parts together, and is what I actually used on the laser cutter. http://pd-la.info/2011/04/pd-la-usb-stick/

Cut one top, one bottom, and two middle pieces from 1/8" plywood.  Blue bottom and middle pieces together with wood glue.  Remove one USB stick from its enclosure and pace it inside.  Glue top in place.  You may want to use a non-conductive adhesive to hold stick in place (silicone adhesive works well, but hot glue would probably work, too).
Design is for most common size of usb drive PCB.  There are drives that have boards which won't fit.
1/8" acrylic would work as well, of course.

title: Sunhokey X-Carriage Fan Holder and Mod to Maximize Build Height Z-200mm

description.text:
Hi Everyone I have a Sunhokey Prusa I3 3D printer that works quite pretty good and even so I still tinker and made some modifications to make it better. The previous improvements/modifications I have done are the following:
-http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:813458
-http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:800771
-http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:640943 Now the printer were supposed to have a build size of 200 x 200 x 180 but due to the size of the borosilicate glass and the clamp obstructing the hot end movement, the achievable build size is 180 x 180 x 180. From my previous improvement (above link) I managed to extend the X-Y area by using terminal lugs clamping method. Now I have a 195 x 190 x 180 build size. But I did not stop there specially when I noticed that the hot end position on the X-carriage is too low and I thought I could get at least 20mm additional Z height if I can just reposition the nozzle/hot end. At the same time the cooling fan position is quite annoying and the fan bumps to the right Z-carriage when I maximize my X travel. So I decided to design a new X-carriage with the nozzle positioned 20mm higher and the cooling fan located inside the carriage assembly (not protruding the X-carriage to prevent it from hitting the right Z-carriage). See photos for details.
Photos shows my prototype and I have made a bit of revisions so the attached OBJ files are the latest revisions which gives better result I believe. I prefer to print flat oriented object since it's a lot stronger compared to object printed with upright/vertical oriented portion so my X-carriage design were divided to flat objects and just fastened it using super glue or screws. Oh and I hate using nut on the screws so I just provided screw holes and forced thread it using the existing screws. LOL The result is quite good. I now have a seemingly compact X-carriage with the cooling fan tucked inside and the nozzle positioned higher giving me additional 20mm Z height. My build size capability now is X195 x Y190 x Z200. By the way, if ever you don't want to apply the whole modification and just wanted the cooling fan holder, you can just print the fan holder and install it to the original acrylic X-carriage since the dimensions of my design was based from the original.
My design is also made to fit small/short slider block (original setup) and big/longer slider block. Hope this will be helpful to everyone too and really love to see it applied to your Sunhokey printer :) Keep printing everyone.... cheers! P.S.
I just wanted to show a sample print of my printer and the quality is really comparable to those expensive 3D printer of the same type (FDM technology). Size of the skull is 30~40mm UPDATES/REVISIONS (May 11, 2015)
I made a Version 3 of the Main part A and B (screw holes provided). The revision was triggered when I made this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820510
It made me realized that it would be much easier to put the timing belt if the timing belt holder is removable. UPDATES (June 9, 2015)
I made a modified Z-endstop holder to go along with this improvement. You can find it here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:640943

description.text:
this is the first thing I have uploaded. it came out a little bad, but I just    messed up a little bit. pleez  tell me how yours came out.  
ps. I apologize for the piteicture I used my laptop cam.

So /u/flycouch on reddit had the idea of taking artwork and converting it to a 3D printable form so the texture could be felt by those with visual impairment. I think this is a great idea so I've created this *.stl of the mona lisa, along with an explanation of how to do your own. This can be done with any image, just by following these steps: 1/ Convert your image to greyscale. There are free online services to do this, or you could use photoshop or a free alternative like gimp. 2/ Upload your greyscale image to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ to generate a lithophane. This wil convert your greyscale to a lithophane. For some reason it makes the lighter areas thicker, so you would normally need to invert it for a lithophane. That is not neccessary here. In your printing software, scale the depth up by about a factor of 2 to increase the texture. A nice acetone smooth after the print is complete should help avoid any rougher edges, and make it feel nicer to the touch, which is important here. If the resolution of the picture is high, you will end up with an extremely large file that takes a long time to slice. Importing the STL into Blender (a free program) and applying a 'decimate' function, you can reduce the number of polygons, and export it as a smaller STL. Even on my faster PC, this reduced polygon model still takes some time to slice 0.3mm. 0.1mm would take longer still.

author: slipshine

description.text:
This bracket allows you to mount a common style of 24 volt power supply to your Ultimaker using 3 existing holes in the frame.  
I am in the process of adding a heated bed to my Ultimaker, so one of the first steps is upgrading to a power supply that can handle the added load of the heater.

I printed with 0.8 mm wall and 35% fill.  
Requires (4) 4 mm x 10 mm flat head screws (to attach bracket to power supply) and (2) 3 mm x 12 mm screws to attach the adaptor to the frame and (2) M3 hex nuts.  The third screws that attaches  the bracket utilizes one of the controller board screws.  Mount the adaptor to the power supply first (be sure to insert the two M3 hex nuts into the hex recesses on the adapter bracket.  If you want to use the cord grip shown in the photos, you'll need one more 4 mm x 10 mm flat head screw.  
The model included here is slightly different than the one I made.  After I printed mine, I realized that it did not need to be so wide.  
The other advantage of this bracket is that it allows for better airflow around the power supply versus mounting it directly against the frame.  Of course, you'll need extended feet to make the appropriate clearance.  This also requires a different fan assembly other than the stock version.  There are several available on Thingiverse.  I used hugokernal's thing:40670 because I had the fans.  My fans are deep and required extra long feet.  I think I'll investigate Sonarok's thing:28498.

title: Kossel Mini Carriage with integrated straight belt slots

description.text: Can someone who has printed this please confirm that the belt slot size was correct for them. I made it fit for my printer, but I'd like confirmation that the slots print well on other printers too. The belt should slide in reasonably easily but then be secure once inserted. Designed for GT2 belt, 6mm wide, 2mm pitch. https://www.adafruit.com/product/1184 Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221667 I wanted to add strength by increasing the thickness of the belt holding parts. It also created empty space at the top to make inserting the nuts easier. The straight belt slots make it much easier to put the belts in. First insert the bottom end of the belt in to the middle slot, wrap the belt around the pulleys, then pull down on the top end to make it tight and slide it in to the remaining slot. I also made the teeth a little deeper. You may need to modify the width of the belt slots depending on your printer. I have added a second file which is the same part but using the original reprap stl file (https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel/blob/master/carriage.stl) as the base. My intention was to minimise any differences from the original part. The belts slots are the same in both files.

comments.text: Since you asked for feedback : for my print, the belt slides out of the slot with little effort. Printed on an Original Prusa i3 Mk2 in PETG at 30mm/s.

description.text: Quick printing lace doily, printed in PLA and turned into a bowl using the oven.  (See instructions area.)

Doily is printed flat in PLA. To turn it into a bowl, do the following: Heat the oven to 215°F.
Cover a cookie tray with aluminum foil. Turn a Pyrex bowl upside down on the cookie tray. Cover that with foil pressed tightly into shape. Put the foil covered bowl into the oven to preheat. After a few minutes, place the doily on top of the bowl and close the oven door. Within a minute (or less) the PLA doily will begin to slump. Watch it closely, you want it to start to curl but not completely lose shape. Open the oven door, place your hands on top of the doily and press down to shape it to the bottom of the bowl. (It's not really hot yet, just soft.) Take it out and it will harden into shape in a few seconds. Use a large bowl for a wide lace bowl, or a small one to get a ruffled effect.

comments.text:
215 Fahrenheit is ~100 Celsius.
Boiled water also works fine.
Short dip - form by hand - repeat :)
You can also try kettle steam, but you must be careful.

description.text:
This is a mounting bracket designed for attaching things to walls. I tried to make it relatively strong and look half decent. The edges could be rounded, the support could go to the middle of the "shelf" rather than the end of it, and the lip at the end could look less awkward, but it should at least be functional.
There are two versions. One has holes in the top and the bottom, as well as another hole in the support so you can actually get to the hole in the bottom with a drill. I'm a little Blender-challenged, especially when it comes to measurements, so I don't know the exact diameter of the holes, but I was aiming for about 3mm. That should be about the size of your standard dry-wall screw. The other version has no holes in case my estimation was totally off, if you want to use another size screw, scale the model up and use the same size screw, or whatever.

Decide whether you want holes or no holes. (Once my Makerbot is running I'll print one out and see if I got the size right.)
Print the brackets, drill holes if necessary, and mount them on the wall! Not knowing how strong ABS is or how thick the plastic will be when printed, I wouldn't recommend putting more than 5lbs or so on these things. You should probably test them out a few times before you put your full confidence in them.
Ultimaker extruder clean tool to keep on the machine. It easily helps to detacht the extruder bolt and claen it.

There are cutouts so you can see how the innards work or learn to lockpick with this thing if you so desire.  
Everything is parametric... at the top of the file there is a bitting array... give it some random numbers between 1 and 10, and it will make the appropriate pins and key... and you can add more numbers if you want!  Have fun building a 27 pin lock!   
If anybody has any advice for getting the thing to print easier or better, please let me know!

Size the pins and stack height according to whatever springs you have, choose your bitting, generate the files, and print them on a powder printer!  Once you have, remove the lid by pinching together the two tails that stick out the back, insert springs, and replace the lid one pin at a time from back to front.  If all goes well, you should be able to insert your key and open the lock.  
And then click "I made one" so I will know you successfully printed it!

description.text:
My gf wanted some pink on her pistol for her birthday and since it was a cheap .22 for getting comfortable plinking I decided it wasn't worth it to have it cerakoted professionally and went at it with some spray paint.  It turned out better than expected so forgive me if there are too many pics, I'm proud of my spray job :P  
Anyway, this tool was envisioned as a means to assist a user with um.... delicate fingers.. in field-stripping or changing barrels in order to make using and cleaning the firearm more enjoyable.  It was modeled with one extrusion operation both because of my n00b skills in NX and to make it as compact (almost wallet-sized) as possible so it's available when you want it to be.  
It also looks kind of starfighter-like, and could be used as a self-defense shank if needed!!

description.text: Give to anyone and let them wonder how these impossible dovetail joints were assembled... Like all my impossible objects, I've published a tutorial on my blog to model this with inventor using the master sketch method (http://wp.me/p3gI7M-64)

No real difficulty to print these pieces. Mine are in PLA, 0.25mm layers, 2 shells no support. The overhangs shouldn't be complex to print.  
There is a 0.5mm clearance in the dovetails. I first printed these piece and they were sliding too easily to my taste. You don't want the puzzle to come loose when someone is handeling it, it would ruin the charm.   
So I've regenerated the files with a 0.25mm clearance (in the zip). I just reprinted the PartA in 0.25mm and with the partB 0.5mm the result is perfectly snapped.

title: Human skull, anatomically correct and printer friendly **updated with jaw**

description.text:
Full human skull, sliced for 3D printing. I started with a 3D model of the individual bones of the skull, then merged and sliced. It took me a couple tries with slicing to find a way to get it to print with a makerbot, but I think I got it working. There are 3 STL files for the skull, top, middle, bottom. Print them each with the largest flat side down, then glue said pieces together. It has a few small overhangs, but overall prints pretty well. I sliced with netfabb, and I've included the original netfabb files and meshes that I made in case anyone else wants to edit it. One is of the slices, and the other has all the bones labeled. The original skull mode came from BodyParts3D. The BodyParts3D uses a creative commons/share-alike license. For more models, see:
http://lifesciencedb.jp/bp3d/?lng=en. **Update 7/19: added a mandible with teeth in a nice, printer-friendly format. Enjoy!
Print the bottom and middle files with the largest flat surface down. Then superglue everything together.

I drew this because I wanted to see if I could make one that worked right off the line without modification. title: Empire and Rebellion Drink Coaster Set (functional!)

description.text: Edit (someDate.ToString()): Print finished a while ago, perfected black on white look, going to attempt rebel one soon, then will post pics.  Works just as well if not better than anticipated (my buddies love it!).

Found these cool galactic coasters (Thing: 19098) but they were lacking in functionality, since water would trickle down the cup and through the cracks in the logos, defeating the purpose of the coaster.  Loved the idea, but it needed a remix.  
I merely added a parametrized disc and did some rendering (took a while... I'm still learning NX) but the result should be much better.  This object is still printing, but I have high hopes that it will work properly so I am releasing before testing.

I am printing at 10% infill, 2 shells, and .2mm resolution in PLA for desired colors but these can be whatever you'd like. To make the dual color type without using dual extruders, I did the following: (may only work with .2mm layer height, haven't tested anything else)
Rebel Alliance Coaster:
10% infill, 2 shells, .2mm layer height Set pause at Z-pos to 4.2 mm and change from white to red filament when paused. The first layer of the symbol is at 4.2 mm. Galactic Empire Coaster:
10% infill, 2 shells, .2mm layer height Start printing in black filament, and set the pause at Z-pos to 3.4mm. When paused, change to white filament. This is the first roof layer, and through trial and error, you need 3.4, 3.6, 3.8 and 4.0mm to all be printed in white for the black to not show through (unfortunately). Set the pause at Z-pos to 4.2 mm similarly to the Rebel coaster to catch the symbol. When it pauses, switch back to black and let it go. Voila! Super cool Star Wars coasters!!! Remixed from Thing: 19098

comments.text: I tried printing this today with a Flashforge Creator Pro with dual extruders. It only printed with one extruder. Is this file only set up for a single extruder? Thanks for any help you can give. Love these designs!

comments.text: Thanks! Yes two extruders requires two separate mesh files, so inputting only one results in a single extrusion print. You are supposed to pause and change the filament mid-print for pictured results. Read instructions for instructions.
